etymology.description: 人(人) (rén, 'person') + 人(人) (rén, 'person') = two people facing each other
etymology.interpretation: The character is a visual depiction of two human forms arranged as if they are facing each other, representing the concept directly.

examples.chinese: 两位候选人 𠨍 辩论(兩位候選人 𠨍 辯論)。
examples.pinyin: Liǎng wèi hòuxuǎn rén miàn duì biànlùn.
examples.english: The two candidates face each other and debate.

examples.chinese: 会议上双方对峙(會議上雙方對峙)，仅凭 𠨍 解读意图(僅憑 𠨍 解讀意圖)。
examples.pinyin: Huìyì shàng shuāngfāng duìzhì, jǐn píng miàn duì jiědú yìtú.
examples.english: At the meeting, both sides confronted each other, solely interpreting intentions by facing each other.
